author: Susan Bugg
title: A day trip from Paris to Monet’s Garden at Giverny with Fat Tire Bike Tours | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | |
text:
YOU’D have to wonder what French Impressionist Claude Monet would make of our modern-day preferences for low-maintenance gardens and neutral home decor.
“Mais, non!” would be my guess after a visit to the glorious house and gardens 75km outside Paris where the light and colour-obsessed artist lived and painted for 40 years until his death in 1926 at the grand age of 86.
The gardens are a dense, wild carnival of tulips, forget-me-nots and irises, cherry tree and crabapple boughs still heavy with blossom in the middle of a French spring.
The house, inside and out, is just as vibrant, with its pale pink stucco exterior, grass-green shutters and doors, two-toned blue sitting room and a yellow dining room so bright you might want to leave your sunglasses on.
Monet's Japanese-influenced water garden. Picture: Fat Tire Bike Tours. Source: Supplied
It is said that Monet, on the hunt for a new family home, fell in love with this former cider farm in the hamlet of Giverny, near the Normandy village of Vernon, as he saw it from a railway carriage window. He moved in, and over the next decades diverted a waterway to create a willow-washed ornamental lake and selected and tended plants to create a legacy not only for the art world but for garden lovers around the globe.
As the artist’s quest may have done on that auspicious day, my journey to Giverny started at Gare Saint-Lazare, a railway hub itself immortalised by Monet in a series of paintings 130 years ago. The smoking steam engines he committed to canvas are long gone, but Saint-Lazare is still one the busiest stations in Paris.
It’s easy enough to catch the train 45 minutes to Vernon and from there find a cab, hire a bike or even walk to Giverny. But after a few days alone in the French capital, I was ready for some company. I headed to Platform 22 where, amid the morning commuters, I joined about 35 others embarking on a day trip to Monet’s Garden with Fat Tire Bike Tours. As the name suggests, the company, founded by an American 16 years ago to show Paris to English-speaking visitors, specialises in seeing the sights on two wheels. On the bike path to Monet’s Garden. Picture: Fat Tire Bike Tours. Source: Supplied
Our bikes, waiting for us in a lockup in Vernon, turned out to be sturdy, comfortable cruisers, suitable for a group that ranged in age from teens travelling with their mums to older couples closing in on retirement.
Giverny was a 4-5km ride away but first, seats adjusted and bags stowed in baskets or racks, we tentatively put foot to pedal to follow our guide, Yorkshireman Drew, to the local market to buy supplies for lunch.
Drew recommended we pick up meat and cheese by the slice, fruit, tomatoes and Normandy’s famous cider from the stallholders – “the word for slice is tranche,” he said – but pointed in the direction of a bakery where we could buy the best baguettes in town (and Boulangerie Rose’s fruit tarts, eclairs and pastries proved just as irresistible as its bread sticks).
After riding through Vernon, stopping briefly to check out its medieval cathedral and ancient lanes, we picnicked on the grass by the Seine, flanked by two of the town’s historic landmarks: the half-timbered Old Mill building perched over the water in front of us and the turrets of 900-year-old Chateau des Tourelles to our back. Monet’s house at Giverny. Picture: Fat Tire Bike Tours. Source: Supplied
If it wasn’t for the spectacle waiting down the 3km bike path from the Seine to Giverny, it would have been easy to while away the afternoon drinking cider, eating strawberries and watching the river.
The bike path followed an old railway route, mostly flat and mostly straight, gentle enough for even an inexperienced cyclist. Soon we rolled into Giverny, past the village church where Monet lies in a crypt with other members of his family.
The serenity, after the busyness of Paris, was refreshing. And so was not having to queue to get into the gardens for more than a minute or two – one of the benefits of being on a “skip-the-line” tour.
Behind the stone walls was the Japanese-style water garden that Monet painted over and over at different times of the day and different times of the year.
Though most visitors filing around the lake had phones at the ready to take snaps of its famous wooden bridge, a few traditionalists sat on benches with watercolours and sketchbooks. A second formal flower garden called Clos Normand is arranged in blocks of colour like an artist’s palette in front of Monet’s house. Paintings of Clos Normand are less common, though if you visit the Musee D’Orsay in Paris, as I had just days earlier, you can see a gilt-framed sea of irises along with some of his other Impressionist masterpieces. Quintessential French picnic. Source: Supplied
Irises still bloom in spring, but the gardens that we see today aren’t the ones that Monet painted.
They fell into disrepair after World War II; along with paintings, Monet’s son Michel bequeathed the property to the Academie des Beaux-Artes upon his death in 1966 but it wasn’t until the ’70s that Gerald Van der Kemp, who had overseen the restoration of another great French cultural treasure, Versailles, raised enough money to resurrect the Giverny house and gardens from weeds, rot and ruin.
They welcomed the first public guests in 1980.
The gardens are open from the end of March until the beginning of November and no matter what time of year you visit, there is always something to see.
From June, mauve and white wisteria tumble from the bridge across the ornamental lake, in July the famous waterlilies bloom on the lake and liquidambar trees turn orange gold as autumn arrives. A team of gardeners works like invisible menders, tidying up and removing spent blooms to keep everything looking its freshest. The studio where Monet painted his vast waterlily murals, prized in art institutions around the world, is now a giftshop selling souvenirs ranging from postcards through to designer jewellery and dinnerware.
I left with a book detailing the planting schemes for the gardens throughout the seasons, and daydreamed on the bike and train ride back to Paris of re-creating an impressionist garden bed on the other side of the world.
